description: Decimal expansion of i^(-i), where i = sqrt(-1).
comments: Square root of Gelfond's constant (A039661). Since Gelfond's constant e^Pi is transcendental, e^(Pi/2) is transcendental. - _Daniel Forgues_, Apr 15 2011The complex sequence (...((((i)^i)^i)^i)^...) (n pairs of brackets) is periodic with period 4 and the first four entries are i, e^(-Pi/2), -i, e^(+Pi/2). See A049006 for e^(-Pi/2). - _Wolfdieter Lang_, Apr 27 2013A solution of x^i + x^(-i) = 0. In fact, x = Exp(Pi/2 + k*Pi), where k is any integer. - _Robert G. Wilson v_, Feb 04 2014
links: Nathaniel Johnston, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
formula: i^(-i) = i^(1/i) = e^(Pi/2).Also (((i)^i)^i)^i. See a comment above on such powers. - _Wolfdieter Lang_, Apr 27 2013
mathematica: RealDigits[Re[I^(1/I)], 10, 100][[1]] (* _Alonso del Arte_, Oct 31 2011 *)RealDigits[ Exp[Pi/2], 10, 111][[1]] (* _Robert G. Wilson v_, Apr 08 2014 *)
prog: (PARI) { default(realprecision, 10100); x=exp(1)^(Pi/2); for (n=1, 10000, d=floor(x); x=(x-d)*10; write("b042972.txt", n, " ", d)); } \\ _Nathaniel Johnston_, Apr 15 2011
author: _Marvin Ray Burns_
